title: 107_hr2787
content: SECTION 1. REFERENCE. This Act amends sections of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. SEC. 2. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE. Congress makes findings related to the workforce participation of mothers with young children, the prevalence of disabilities among children under 6, and the requirements of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act for early intervention and special education services. The General Accounting Office also highlights issues with the supply of infant care and care for special needs children. The General Accounting Office reports limited supply of infant care, care for special needs children, and care during nonstandard hours. Children with disabilities face barriers in accessing child care programs due to myths, stereotypes, and lack of staff training. The purpose of this Act is to increase quality child care for children with disabilities. The Act aims to improve child care quality by including families with children with disabilities in the application and plan. It also focuses on activities to enhance child care for children with disabilities. Section 658G (42 U.S.C. 9858e) is amended to require states to allocate at least 5 percent of funds for activities that improve child care for children with disabilities. The amendment to Section 658G requires states to allocate 5% of funds for activities that improve child care for children with disabilities, including training and technical assistance for child care providers, licensing agencies, and parents on implementing disability laws. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act provides technical assistance and training for child care providers to include children with disabilities in child care settings. This includes training on assistive technology and developing leadership skills for inclusive child care programs. The curr_chunk discusses grants for recruitment and retention of qualified staff in child care programs, including scholarships for staff working with children with and without disabilities to obtain associate degrees. It also mentions assistance to child care resource and referral agencies on compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. Grants are provided to child care staff to obtain degrees or training in child development, increase salaries, and retain qualified providers. Low-interest loans are also available for projects that enhance child care programs. The program provides grants and low-interest loans to public agencies and nonprofit organizations for projects that increase availability of inclusive child care programs, child care for infants, and child care during evenings and weekends. SEC. 5. REPORTS. Amended to include disability status. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. Amends Section 658P to define "child with a disability" and "inclusive child care program."
